TopicTitle: EVAing Kerbals on ladders won't stay put!

Articles.Content:
While rescuing errant Kerbals and their derelict crafts, I am using the KIS+KAS mods to attach the necessary parts for their safe return to Kerbin.  For the attachment of larger parts (like heat shields), more than one engineer is needed, so I try to position them on strategically-placed ladders during the assembly.  However, the Kerbals won't always stay put on the ladder - they slowly drift up or down, regardless of whether the vehicle is in orbit or landed.  It gets frustrating when you have to constantly toggle between the Kerbals to keep them in the right place, or worse, have to fire up their jetpack yet again to put them back on the ladder.

What causes them to move?  Is there anything to be done to make them stay put?  Can I hope this behavior has been (or will be) eliminated in the 1.1.x (or 1.2) versions?

I'm using KSP v1.0.4 with only minimal mods: KER, KIS and KAS.

Just as aside: why does the Hitchhiker container sport what appears to be handrails all around the top and bottom edges, but Kerbals cannot grab any of them?

The top and bottom edge 'handrails' are just cosmetic.  You will need to place ladder segments to move around the circumference.

The sliding up and down ladders is a bug that has been there since the beginning, best not to get hung up on it.

You can do something to make them stay put - place some stopper features on the ladder tracks.  Some of the small science experiment parts (pressure, seismic etc) work.  The surface-mount batteries might be more useful to you for the part count.  Experiment!

9 hours ago, psychogre said:

more than one engineer is needed

Hello,

Note that you always need only one "tooled" engineer. The others "assistants" kerbal might have any profession. (I usually mount my space stations in orbit with my typical crew of 1 eng, 2 sci and 1 pilot.)

I also have the "ladder problem". The best way I found to maintain 3 uncontrolled kerbals + 1 controlled eng in the 3m range of a sci lab (3.5t) is to put a ladder with KIS at 90° of the surface or in an module angle. With luck your kerbal will glide toward the module. (I can post some pictures if needed later.)

You will also note that the gliding direction depend of the ship/ladder orientation.

See you,

Vive_moi

I got the best idea ever.

Make a "satellite" with like 12 winches on the nose of it and enough seating for however many engineers you need. Then when you get to were you need to construct, just winch all your kerbals to the ship and park the ship close.

 

10/10

14 hours ago, Vive_moi said:

Note that you always need only one "tooled" engineer. The others "assistants" kerbal might have any profession.

Thanks - that's a useful tip!

I have experimented with various angles of ladders, but haven't gotten consistent results on whether the Kerbals drift or not.  I found that docking ports and batteries work as good stops, but the radial mounted parachutes do not.

At least I now know it's not just me...

Despite the issue, I am absolutely thrilled to be able to salvage and re-use the various cast-off parts from earlier flights in my career.  Gives a new aspect to think about when planning the next mission!

On 8/9/2016 at 5:32 PM, psychogre said:

I have experimented with various angles of ladders, but haven't gotten consistent results on whether the Kerbals drift or not.

It's not just ladder angle, it's also something about the ship situation (some mysterious combination of ship orientation, position, whether it's landed and if so where and at what angle, and potentially other factors I've never been able to determine).  I've had experiences where kerbals will sometimes drift up, sometimes down, sometimes stay put, or be at varying drift speeds, for the same ship at different times.

I have no idea what actually causes it (not sure if anyone does).  I assume it's some subtle bug in the physics engine and/or the KSP code that interacts with it.  The problem has been around (and well-known) since forever (certainly since before I started playing, back in 0.23.5 more than two years ago, which is forever in KSP-time).  It's annoying, would be great if they could fix it... but I assume that fixing it must be non-trivial or they would have done it already.

Anyway... no, it's not you, happens to everyone, and the only strategy I know of is "just put up with it and hope it gets fixed someday."
